Detailed Description

A helper class meant to aid logging.

This is a class used to aid in the output of information. It is meant as an actual replacement for the built in std::cout and std::cerr functions. This class automatically places spaces between passed data, automatically adds an endline after you're done outputing. Further features include support for a small set of string replacement tags for easy inserting of time, class names, line numbers, etc..., built in indentation, leveled output (trace, debug, info, warn, error), and redirection of output to a file or the console. The debug level may be set at compile time allowing certain messages to be completely removed from the code resulting in absolutely zero performance loss (the downside to this is the necessity of macros).

This class is not meant to be used directly, rather the utility macros below make use of this class to generate output. The 5 macros currently supported are:

  • Trace
  • Debug
  • Info
  • Warn
  • Error

Each macro has its own trace level associated with it. As stated before, output levels can be adjusted at compile and run time (though compile acts as a hard cull). By setting the log level to InfoMessage, only messages of level Info, Warn, and Error will be output. Usage for these methods are as follows: Debug("Some debug output.");

This logger will allow certain built in text replacements to make certain output easier. Tags to be automatically replaced are marked with the % sign followed by a letter to indicate what the tag should be replaced with. Here is a list of currently supported tags: f - File t - Time l - Line

Just like C++'s cout and cerr methods, this logger makes use of ostreams. As such, variable insertion is very similar to cout and cerr. Remember that whitespace is added automatically after each pipe. Here is an example of adding variables to output and using the automatic replacement tags:

int a = 5, b = 1; Debug("[%t]" << a << "*" << b << "=" << a); // Outputs: [18:30] 5 * 1 = 5

If you always want the time prepended to your output, you may also call SetPretext passing in "[%t]".

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum LogStream::LogType

LogType enumerates the different log levels available to the system.

Enumerator:
TraceMessage  Used for tracing the codepath.
DebugMessage  Used to help find errors in the code.
InfoMessage  Used for generic information that would be helpful.
WarningMessage  Used when questionable behavior arises.
ErrorMessage  Used to log errors that could have major repercussions.
NoOutput  Used simply to shut off all output.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

LogStream::LogStream ( LogType  type,
bool  endline,
const string &  file,
int  line 
)

Initializes LogStream class with the appropriate LogType.

Parameters:
type Enum representing the log level associated with this object.
endline If 'true' an endline will be printed during the d'tor.
file The name of the file output is coming from.
line The line number the output is coming from.

LogStream::~LogStream (  ) 

Prints the posttext, an endline if specified in the constructor and kills the program on fatal messages (unless AbortOnError has been set to false).

Member Function Documentation

static void LogStream::SetPretext ( const string &  text  )  [static]

Sets the pretext string that is printed as the object is being created.

Parameters:
text The text to print out during object construction (Usually spaces).

void LogStream::SetIndentLevel ( int  level  )  [static]

Sets an indent level for output. By setting the indent level, leading whitespace is added to all output to aid in clarity.

Parameters:
level The number of indentations to place before output.
See also:
setIndentSize(int size)

Increases the indent level by a certain ammount.

Parameters:
number The number to increment the current level by.
See also:

void LogStream::SetIndentSize ( int  size  )  [static]

Sets the number of spaces per indentation.

Parameters:
size The number of spaces in a single indentation.

void LogStream::SetAbortOnError ( bool  abort  )  [static]

Sets the a parameter that determines if LogType 'Error' messages will cause the program to abort once the message has been printed out. This may make debugging certain errors easier.

Parameters:
abort The new value to determine if errors result in an abort.

static void LogStream::SetLogTarget ( const string &  filename  )  [static]

This function is used to determine where program output is directed. Output can be sent to a log file or standard out.

Parameters:
filename Sets the file to log to. If this value is NULL, logging will go to standard out.

void LogStream::SetLogLevel ( LogType  level  )  [static]

This allows the user to control just how much output is generated by the program. 'DebugMessage' will generate the most output, while 'FatalMessage' will generate the least and 'NoOutput' will not generate any at all.

Parameters:
level The minimum level of output to actually log.

void LogStream::ClearLogFile (  )  [static]

This will delete the old log file.

bool LogStream::GetAbortOnError (  )  [static]

Tells the caller if the abort on error flag is set.

Returns:
true if the abort on error flag is set, false otherwise.

void LogStream::Test (  )  [static]

Runs the test suite for the LogStream class. Any failures will result in a problem description to 'cerr' followed by an abort().

template<typename T>
LogStream & LogStream::operator<< ( const T &  rhs  )  [inline]

This is the actual stream operator that allows output. Any data passed to this function will be sent on to the current log target. After every piece of data it prints, a ' ' is inserted for ease of use. Note that strings and char*s are handled in overloaded methods. The only difference is they do a tag replacement before printing out.

Parameters:
rhs The data type to be logged. Can be any type that implements the '<<' operator for output.
Returns:
A reference to the LogStream for function chaining.

LogStream & LogStream::operator<< ( char *  rhs  ) 

Overloaded version of the templated function.

See also:
template <typename t>=""> LogStream& operator<<(const T &rhs)

LogStream & LogStream::operator<< ( const char *  rhs  ) 

Overloaded version of the templated function.

See also:

Overloaded version of the templated function.

const string& LogStream::replaceTags ( const string &  original,
string &  temp 
) [protected]

Scans through a string and replaces all of the tags with their correct values.

Parameters:
original The string to scan through.
temp If any tags are found, the new string will be stored in temp.
Returns:
If there are any tags, a reference to temp is returned, otherwise a reference to original is returned

void LogStream::output ( const string &  format  )  [inline, protected]

This method simply does a logging output for strings. The only difference is that it calls the replaceTags method.

Parameters:
format The string to print out (with or without tags).

void LogStream::PrintAndCheckResult ( char *  string,
LogType  output = InfoMessage 
) [static, protected]

This function is used to test the result of a simple output operation. It simply outputs the given string at the given log level and returns the result.

Parameters:
string The string to output AND the result of the operation.
output The level at which to output the string.

void LogStream::CheckResult ( char *  string  )  [static, protected]

This function simply reads the current log file into the string. Meant for testing purposes.

Parameters:
string The result of the file read.

static void LogStream::AppendTimeString ( string &  timeless  )  [static, protected]

Appends the time to the end if the given string. Time is always in the form HH:MM and in 24 hour time.

Parameters:
timeless The string that needs the time appended to it.

Field Documentation

bool LogStream::_endline [protected]

Determines if a newline will be output by the d'tor.

LogType LogStream::_type [protected]

Determines the level of the current log object (for culling).

string LogStream::_file [protected]

The name of the file from which the log method was called.

The line number from which the log method was called.

A variable that notes if any output has occured yet.

The stream to which output is redirected.

string LogStream::Logfile = "" [static, protected]

The name of the file to log to (stdout if "").

Text to prepend to log output.

bool LogStream::AbortOnError = false [static, protected]

Determines if the program dies after an error.

LogStream::LogType LogStream::LogLevel = InfoMessage [static, protected]

The last level to allow logging at.

int LogStream::IndentLevel = 0 [static, protected]

The number of indentations to prepend output with.

The size of the indentations prepended to output.
